trivia: Essaouira served as a filming location for Game of Thrones, appearing as the city of Astapor where Daenerys Targaryen acquired her army of Unsullied.
Jimi Hendrix visited in 1969, inspiring rumors that his song 'Castles Made of Sand' was written about the city (though it was actually released two years before his visit).

clues: This Rajasthani city is known as the 'Blue City' for its azure-painted buildings.
Famous for its imposing hilltop fort, colorful markets, and distinctive riding breeches named after it.
fun_fact: Jodhpur's blue-painted houses were originally associated with Brahmins (the highest Hindu caste), but the color was later adopted by others as it was believed to repel insects and keep homes cool.
The city's Mehrangarh Fort sits 400 feet above the city on a perpendicular cliff, making it one of the most impressive fortress complexes in India.
trivia: Jodhpur gave its name to jodhpur riding pants, which were popularized by the city's polo-playing royals and later became a global fashion item.
The fort's museum houses one of India's best collections of royal palanquins, elephant howdahs, and the royal cradles of multiple generations.

clues: This resort town on a lake is known as the 'Adventure Capital of the World.'
Famous for bungee jumping, skiing, and dramatic landscapes featured in Lord of the Rings.
fun_fact: Queenstown is home to the world's first commercial bungee jumping operation, which began at Kawarau Bridge in 1988.
The town was named 'Queenstown' because it was 'fit for Queen Victoria' according to early gold prospectors.
trivia: Despite its reputation for extreme sports, the town was originally settled during the gold rush of the 1860s.
Scenes from the Lord of the Rings trilogy were filmed in the mountains surrounding Queenstown, with nearby areas serving as Lothlorien, Isengard, and the Misty Mountains.

clues: This ancient Incan city sits high in the Andes Mountains and was unknown to the outside world until 1911.
Known for its perfectly fitted stone structures built without mortar and stunning mountain views.
fun_fact: Machu Picchu was built in the 15th century but abandoned about 100 years later, likely due to a smallpox epidemic brought by Spanish conquerors who never actually discovered it.
The site's buildings are designed to withstand earthquakes with stones cut so precisely they don't need mortar and can slightly shift during seismic activity without collapsing.
trivia: The name Machu Picchu means 'Old Mountain' in the Quechua language, while the mountain facing it is Huayna Picchu ('Young Mountain').
The site was made a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1983 and named one of the New Seven Wonders of the World in 2007.

clues: This East African island city is known for its historic Stone Town district and spice markets.
Famous for its narrow winding streets, ornate wooden doors, and history as a spice trading hub.
fun_fact: Zanzibar was once the world's largest producer of cloves, and even today the islands produce about 80% of Tanzania's clove exports.
Stone Town's doors are famous for their elaborate brass studs, which were originally designed to ward off charging elephants during wars in India.
trivia: Freddie Mercury, the lead singer of Queen, was born in Zanzibar when it was still a British protectorate.
Zanzibar briefly held the record for the world's shortest war against Britain in 1896, lasting only 38 minutes before surrender.

clues: This ancient Maya city is known for a step pyramid where shadows create the illusion of a serpent during equinoxes.
Famous for its elaborate stone carvings, observatory, and the largest ball court in Mesoamerica.
fun_fact: Chichén Itzá's main pyramid, El Castillo, is designed with precise astronomical alignment so that during the spring and autumn equinoxes, the setting sun creates a shadow pattern resembling a serpent descending the northern staircase.
The site's acoustics are remarkable—a person standing at the base of El Castillo can clap and hear an echo that sounds like a bird call.
trivia: The Great Ball Court at Chichén Itzá is the largest in the Americas at 168 meters long and 70 meters wide, with surfaces so acoustically perfect that a whisper can be heard from one end to the other.

The site's sacred cenote (natural sinkhole) was used for sacrificial offerings, including human sacrifices, as confirmed by archaeological explorations that recovered gold, jade, pottery, and human bones.

clues: This city is known for its vibrant red buildings and bustling medina (old town).
Famous for its maze-like souks (markets) selling spices, textiles, and handicrafts.
fun_fact: Marrakech is known as the 'Red City' due to the distinctive salmon-pink color of its buildings and walls, which were built using local clay.
The central square, Jemaa el-Fnaa, transforms from a market during the day to an open-air food court and entertainment venue at night.
trivia: Marrakech was founded in 1062 and served as the capital of Morocco for much of its history.
The city's Majorelle Garden was owned by fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent, who requested that his ashes be scattered there after his death.

clues: This West African capital sits on the Cap-Vert peninsula and is known for its vibrant music scene.
Famous for the annual Paris-Dakar Rally, colorful colonial buildings, and beaches.
fun_fact: Dakar hosts the famous off-road endurance rally that originally ran from Paris to this city, though the race now takes place in South America due to security concerns in North Africa.
The city is home to the African Renaissance Monument, at 160 feet tall, the tallest statue in Africa.
trivia: Dakar's Île de Gorée was a departure point for slaves being sent to the Americas, and its House of Slaves is now a museum and memorial.
The city is considered a cultural hub of West Africa, with a significant influence on global music through mbalax, a fusion of Western and traditional Senegalese styles.

clues: This coastal Indian city is known for its classical dance, music, and the world's second longest urban beach.
Formerly known as Madras and famous for its spicy cuisine, temples, and British colonial architecture.
fun_fact: Chennai's Marina Beach stretches for 13 km, making it the second-longest urban beach in the world after Miami's South Beach.
The city is considered the automobile capital of India, producing about 40% of the country's vehicles, earning it the nickname 'The Detroit of India.'
trivia: Chennai is the guardian of Bharatanatyam, one of the oldest classical dance forms, and Carnatic music, the classical music of South India.
The city was established as a British settlement in 1639 when the East India Company purchased land to build Fort St. George, making it one of the first British outposts in India.

clues: This city is known for its sulfur baths and a blend of European and Asian architectural styles.
The capital sits in a valley along the Mtkvari River with colorful houses climbing up the hillsides.
fun_fact: Tbilisi means 'warm place' in Georgian, named after the hot springs discovered when a king's falcon fell into them in the 5th century.
The city has been destroyed and rebuilt at least 29 times due to its strategic location between Europe and Asia.
trivia: Wine-making has been practiced in the Tbilisi region for over 8,000 years, making Georgia one of the oldest wine regions in the world.
The city's ancient sulfur baths feature distinctive brick domes and are still used for their therapeutic properties today.

clues: This Nordic capital is built across a peninsula and 330 islands.
Known for its cutting-edge design, saunas, and a church carved directly into solid rock.
fun_fact: Helsinki's Temppeliaukio Church (Rock Church) is carved directly into natural bedrock, with a ceiling made of a copper wire dome.
The city has more saunas than cars, with an estimated 3 million saunas in a country of 5.5 million people.
trivia: Helsinki has an underground network of shops, museums, swimming pools, and even a church, designed to allow life to continue during harsh winters.
The city was founded by Swedish King Gustav I in 1550 and was originally located at the mouth of the Vantaa River before being moved to its current location.

clues: This city nestled in a valley was once notorious for drug cartels but is now celebrated for its innovative urban planning.
Known as the 'City of Eternal Spring' for its pleasant climate and annual flower festival.
fun_fact: Medellín has an innovative public transportation system that includes cable cars connecting hillside neighborhoods to the city center.
The city transformed from one of the most dangerous in the world in the 1990s to winning the 'World's Most Innovative City' award in 2013.
trivia: Medellín hosts the annual Feria de las Flores (Flower Festival), where silleteros carry enormous flower arrangements on their backs in a traditional parade.
The city's Comuna 13, once one of the most dangerous neighborhoods, is now known for its outdoor escalators, street art, and cultural tours.

clues: This Himalayan capital has ancient temples, bustling markets, and serves as a gateway for mountain climbers.
Known for its Buddhist stupas with watching eyes, intricate wood carvings, and Durbar Square.
fun_fact: Kathmandu's Boudhanath Stupa features Buddha's eyes painted on all four sides, symbolically watching over the four cardinal directions.
The city's Kumari is a prepubescent girl selected from the Shakya clan who is believed to be the incarnation of the Hindu goddess Taleju and lives in a palace in Durbar Square.
trivia: Kathmandu's name derives from an ancient temple made of wood from a single tree, called Kaasthamandap, which sadly collapsed during the 2015 earthquake.
The city has the highest concentration of UNESCO World Heritage Sites among any capital city in the world.

clues: This city is the southernmost city in the world, nicknamed 'The End of the World.'
Known as a gateway to Antarctica and for its dramatic setting between mountains and the Beagle Channel.
fun_fact: Ushuaia is located on Tierra del Fuego island and is the closest major city to Antarctica, about 1,000 km away.
The city began as a penal colony in the early 20th century, with prisoners forced to build much of the early infrastructure, including the 'Train of the End of the World.'
trivia: Despite its extreme southern location, Ushuaia's climate is relatively mild due to oceanic influences, with average winter temperatures similar to Chicago.
The Beagle Channel, on which Ushuaia sits, is named after HMS Beagle, the ship that carried Charles Darwin on his voyage of discovery in the 1830s.

clues: This East Asian capital has one of the world's tallest buildings with a design inspired by bamboo.
Known for its night markets, bubble tea, and blend of Chinese, Japanese, and Western influences.
fun_fact: Taipei 101 was the world's tallest building from 2004 to 2010 and contains a 728-ton steel pendulum that acts as a tuned mass damper to reduce swaying during earthquakes and strong winds.
The city has more than 20 night markets, with Shilin Night Market being one of the largest and most famous in Taiwan.
trivia: Taipei's National Palace Museum houses one of the largest collections of ancient Chinese artifacts and artworks in the world, many brought from mainland China during the Chinese Civil War.
The city is the birthplace of bubble tea (boba tea), the popular drink with chewy tapioca pearls that has spread worldwide.

clues: This Caribbean capital has a historic walled district with blue cobblestone streets and Spanish colonial forts.
Known for its colorful buildings, rum distilleries, and status as the oldest European-established city under U.S. jurisdiction.
fun_fact: San Juan's blue cobblestone streets were originally cast from furnace slag (waste) and were installed as ballast in Spanish ships before being repurposed as paving material.
The city is home to Castillo San Felipe del Morro, a 16th-century citadel that took 250 years to complete and successfully repelled numerous attacks from the English, Dutch, and American forces.
trivia: San Juan was founded in 1521, making it the second-oldest European-established capital city in the Americas, after Santo Domingo.
The Bacardi rum distillery in San Juan is one of the largest premium rum distilleries in the world, producing over 100,000 bottles per day.

clues: This Arabian city is known for its whitewashed buildings nestled between mountains and the sea.
Famous for its ornate Grand Mosque with a hand-woven carpet that once was the world's largest.
fun_fact: Muscat has building codes requiring all structures to incorporate traditional Arabic architectural elements and not exceed a certain height.
The city's name comes from the Arabic word for 'anchorage,' as it has been an important trading port since ancient times.
trivia: Muscat's Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque features a chandelier with 600,000 crystal pieces and can accommodate 20,000 worshippers.
The city has been ruled by the Portuguese, the Ottoman Empire, and the Persians at various points in its history.

clues: This former imperial capital features a massive citadel on the Perfume River.
Known for its royal tombs, historical monuments, and distinctive spicy cuisine.
fun_fact: Hue's Imperial City is a walled fortress and palace that was modeled after Beijing's Forbidden City but suffered severe damage during the Vietnam War.
The city's name is among the shortest in the world with just three letters, but is actually pronounced 'hway' rather than 'hue.'
trivia: Hue's cuisine is known for its complexity, with some traditional royal dishes requiring up to 50 different ingredients.
The city served as Vietnam's capital under the Nguyen Dynasty from 1802 to 1945, the country's last royal dynasty.

clues: This capital city is known as the 'Windy City' and sits at the southern tip of New Zealand's North Island.
Famous for its film industry connections, cable car, and vibrant café culture.
fun_fact: Wellington is the southernmost capital city in the world and experiences strong winds due to its location in the 'Roaring Forties' latitudes.
The city is home to Weta Workshop and Weta Digital, the special effects companies behind The Lord of the Rings, The Hobbit, and many other major films.
trivia: Wellington has more cafés, bars, and restaurants per capita than New York City.
The city's Beehive parliament building is considered one of the world's most unique government buildings, with its distinctive tiered design.

clues: This colonial city in the Yucatán is known for its colorful buildings and proximity to cenotes (natural sinkholes).
Located between Cancún and Mérida, it serves as a gateway to Chichén Itzá.
fun_fact: Valladolid was the site of the Maya uprising called the Caste War, one of the most successful indigenous rebellions in the Americas.
The city sits atop a network of underground cenotes (sinkholes), with the spectacular Cenote Zaci located right in the center of town.
trivia: Valladolid is famous for producing some of the best examples of Yucatecan cuisine, including cochinita pibil (slow-roasted pork) and longaniza sausage.
The city's colonial architecture features a distinctive technique called 'cal-pek,' which combines limestone and sticky tree sap to create colorful facades.

clues: This Australian city is surrounded by parklands and known as the 'City of Churches.'
Famous for its festivals, food and wine regions, and planned grid layout.
fun_fact: Adelaide was the first major city in Australia to be established by free settlers rather than convicts.
The city was designed by Colonel William Light in a grid pattern surrounded by parklands, which was revolutionary urban planning for the 1830s.
trivia: Adelaide hosts the largest arts festival in the Southern Hemisphere, the Adelaide Fringe Festival.
The city is surrounded by over 200 wineries, including the famous Barossa Valley and McLaren Vale regions.

clues: This African port city is known for its Portuguese colonial architecture and acacia-lined avenues.
Famous for its railway station designed by Gustave Eiffel and vibrant markets.
fun_fact: Maputo's Central Railway Station was designed by Gustave Eiffel (of Eiffel Tower fame) and is considered one of the most beautiful train stations in the world.
The city was originally called Lourenço Marques after the Portuguese trader who first explored the area in 1544.
trivia: Maputo is known for its unique blend of African, Portuguese, and Muslim influences, reflected in its architecture, cuisine, and culture.
The city's iconic Samora Machel Statue was built by North Korean artisans, who have constructed similar monuments throughout Africa.

clues: This city is home to a famous white marble mausoleum built by a Mughal emperor for his beloved wife.
Known for the Taj Mahal, Agra Fort, and as a former capital of the Mughal Empire.
fun_fact: The Taj Mahal appears to change color throughout the day, from pinkish in the morning, to white in the afternoon, and golden in the moonlight.
The precious stones that once adorned the walls of the Taj Mahal were ripped out during the Indian Rebellion of 1857.
trivia: The Taj Mahal took over 22 years to complete, employing around 20,000 workers and 1,000 elephants.
Agra was the capital of the Mughal Empire during the 16th and 17th centuries before the capital was shifted to Delhi.

clues: This Central Asian capital holds the world record for the highest concentration of white marble buildings.
Known for its grandiose architecture, gold statues, and unusually empty streets.
fun_fact: Ashgabat holds the Guinness World Record for the highest density of white marble buildings in the world, with over 500 buildings covered in white marble.
The city has a gold-plated statue of a book that automatically opens and plays the national anthem every evening at 8 PM.
trivia: Ashgabat was almost completely destroyed by an earthquake in 1948 that killed nearly two-thirds of the city's population.
The city has built numerous grandiose and unusual monuments, including a giant indoor Ferris wheel and a 75-meter-tall monument topped with a golden statue of the former president.
